hackathon-eligibility:
Students who have registered for HackRU and checked-in to the event are eligible to participate. As per MLH regulations, all hackers must currently be a student or have graduated within the last school year.
All participants are only allowed to be a part of 
Participants MUST print and sign this waiver to be allowed entry.
hackathon-rules:
All projects MUST be submitted to DevPost by 11:30AM on Sunday, April 17. 
All attendees must agree to and sign the provided waiver upon entry.
All attendees are required to adhere to the 
.

HackRU is a community hackathon intended for collaboration and learning in the student community. We value the participation of each member of the student community and want all attendees to have an enjoyable experience. All participants are expected to show respect to other fellow participants throughout the hackathon. All attendees and speakers at HackRU are required to conform to the following Code of Conduct. The organizing team and Rutgers University reserve the right to enforce, revise, and append these rules.
We believe that every individual has the right to hack in a safe and amicable environment. All HackRU participants comply to:

If you feel uncomfortable or think there may be a possible violation of the code of conduct, please report it immediately. All individuals who report remain anonymous. The HackRU Organizers will work to resolve all incidents alongside MLH representatives.

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Pebble Time Round + ($30 Amazon/Watch Band) x 4
HackRU Snapback and $20 Starbucks Gift Card x 4
Pie Sakib and Horse Mask x 4
Swag bags with Sparkfun Redboards x 4

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Use of Edison from Intel Corp
Best Use of the Watson Cognitive APIs from IBM
Best Use of Capital One API

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: $250 Donation Credit towards teachers' projects on DonorsChoose.org x 4
iPad mini and tickets to Tech Crunch Destruct x 4

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: The Most Innovative Embedded Application from L-3 Communications

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Winner gets the chance to present at NJTC's Internet of Things competition at Princeton University on April 26th to a panel of Venture Capital and Angel Investors.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: IoT Princeton Presentation from New Brunswick Office of Innovation

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Winners whose hacks/ solutions can benefit residents of New Brunswick get the opportunity to meet the Mayor of New Brunswick and share their ideas for using tech to improve quality of life for residents of the City.
